body.p:
Second and last governor of the provisional Confederate government of the state of Kentucky. Member of the Whig and Democratic Parties. Educated at Transylvania University in Lexington, Kentucky, and read law with Charles Humphreys and Robert Wickliffe. Married Hetty Morrison Nicholas on November 13, 1818. Father of James Morrison Hawes, George N. Hawes, Samuel Hawes, Smith Nicholas Hawes, Cary Nicholas Hawes, Clara Hawes, Hettie Hawes, and Mariah J. Hawes. Served in the Black Hawk War. Practiced law and farmed in Fayette, Clark, and Bourbon Counties. Owned a ropewalk in Winchester, Kentucky, in partnership with Benjamin Hawes Buckner in 1825.
Represented Clark County in the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky in 1828, 1829, and 1836. Represented the 7th district of Kentucky in the United States House of Representatives from 1837-1841. Appointed a Major in the Confederate Commissary department under Humphrey Marshall on October 18, 1861. Assumed office as Provisional Governor of the Provisional Confederate Government on Kentucky on May 31, 1862, after the death of George W. Johnson. Installed as second and final provisional Confederate governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky on October 4, 1862 and served until the collapse of the Confederacy in 1865.
